
ls() returns objects in character vector.
```{r simple}
x  <- 2
y  <- 2*x
ls()
```

ls() ALSO includes name of functions.
```{r add_fun}
ls()
f  <- function() {
  z  <- 2
}

ls()  # includes f
```

#### and ls() sees environment
```{r ENV}

E1  <- new.env()
ls()
```

#### ls can also examine OTHER environments
```{r other}
ls(envir=E1)

E1$x  <- 2
ls(envir = E1)

```


environment is ....
environment() returns <env>, one of R's typeof
```{r}
environment()
typeof(environment())
```





ls(envir=as.environment("package:usethis"))
And you can add your own, sometimes R creates its won.

Example, Modify f 
```{r modify_f}
ls()

f  <- function() {
  z  <- 2
  print(environment())
  print(ls())
}

ls()  # includes f and g

```

```{r f}
f()
```
